i would like matmul but for operations like relu i have planned to create a seperate class of activation layers which would apply the function How would i then computer the gradient for this
ChatGPT said:

Thats a solid plan separating activation layers into their own class keeps your design clean and extensible. For operations like ReLU, it makes sense to treat them as layers/functions that take a Tensor and return a new one, attaching the appropriate backward logic for autodiff.

How to compute gradients for activation functions

The key is to:

  1. Apply the function (e.g., ReLU) to the input tensor to produce an output tensor.

  2. Attach a .backward() function to the output tensor that knows how to propagate gradients back to the input.

ReLU Example (manual implementation)

Forward:

ReLU(x)=max(0,x)\text{ReLU}(x) = \max(0, x)ReLU(x)=max(0,x)

Backward:

ddxReLU(x)={1if x>00if x0\frac{d}{dx} \text{ReLU}(x) = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } x > 0 \\ 0 & \text{if } x \leq 0 \end{cases}dxdReLU(x)={10if x>0if x0

Example: ReLU Layer as a Function

Assume you already have a Tensor class like the one we discussed.

python
def relu(t: Tensor) -> Tensor:
    out_data = np.maximum(0, t.data)
    out = Tensor(out_data, requires_grad=t.requires_grad)

    def _backward():
        if t.requires_grad:
            relu_grad = (t.data > 0).astype(np.float32)
            t.grad += relu_grad * out.grad

    if out.requires_grad:
        out._backward = _backward
        out._parents = [t]

    return out

Usage Example:

python
x = Tensor([-2.0, 1.0, 3.0], requires_grad=True)
y = relu(x)
z = y * 2
z.backward()

print("Output:", z.data)          # [0. 2. 6.]
print("Gradient:", x.grad)       # [0. 2. 2.]

Why this works

When you call z.backward(), it:

  1. Accumulates dz/dz = 1

  2. Passes this through the multiply node:

    • dz/dy = 2, and forwards this to y

  3. Passes that to the ReLU node:

    • Multiplies by dReLU/dx, which is 0 if input 0

Extend this idea to other activations

You can build a class or module like:

python
class Activation:
    @staticmethod
    def relu(x: Tensor) -> Tensor:
        # as above
        pass

    @staticmethod
    def sigmoid(x: Tensor) -> Tensor:
        # similar: use sigmoid(x) and compute derivative
        pass

Or make each activation a class that behaves like a callable (if you want trainable parameters later, like PReLU or Swish).

Summary

  • You were right to plan for separating activations into their own layer.

  • Each activation returns a new tensor and attaches a custom backward function.

  • The autodiff engine uses the chain rule automatically during backprop.

Would you like me to also show how to implement matmul with backward logic next?

You said:
sure
ChatGPT said:

Great! Lets implement matmul (matrix multiplication) with autodiff support.

Goal

  • Implement forward pass: C = A.matmul(B)

  • Implement backward pass:

    • If C=ABC = A \cdot BC=AB, then:

      • CA=gradBT\frac{\partial C}{\partial A} = \text{grad} \cdot B^TAC=gradBT

      • CB=ATgrad\frac{\partial C}{\partial B} = A^T \cdot \text{grad}BC=ATgrad

matmul Implementation in Python

python
def matmul(a: Tensor, b: Tensor) -> Tensor:
    assert a.data.ndim == 2 and b.data.ndim == 2, "Only 2D matmul is supported for now"
    out = Tensor(np.matmul(a.data, b.data), requires_grad=a.requires_grad or b.requires_grad)
    out._parents = [a, b]

    def _backward():
        if a.requires_grad:
            a.grad += np.matmul(out.grad, b.data.T)
        if b.requires_grad:
            b.grad += np.matmul(a.data.T, out.grad)

    if out.requires_grad:
        out._backward = _backward

    return out

Example Usage

python
A = Tensor([[1.0, 2.0]], requires_grad=True)  # shape (1, 2)
B = Tensor([[3.0], [4.0]], requires_grad=True)  # shape (2, 1)

C = matmul(A, B)  # shape (1, 1)
C.backward()

print("C:", C.data)         # [[11.0]]
print("dC/dA:", A.grad)     # [[3.0, 4.0]]
print("dC/dB:", B.grad)     # [[1.0], [2.0]]

Whats happening:

Let:

  • A=[1,2]A = [1, 2]A=[1,2]

  • B=[[3],[4]]B = [[3], [4]]B=[[3],[4]]

  • Then C=AB=13+24=11C = A \cdot B = 1*3 + 2*4 = 11C=AB=13+24=11

Now, backprop:

  • CA=BT=[3,4]\frac{\partial C}{\partial A} = B^T = [3, 4]AC=BT=[3,4]

  • CB=AT=[[1],[2]]\frac{\partial C}{\partial B} = A^T = [[1], [2]]BC=AT=[[1],[2]]

Expand Later:

You can later extend this:

  • To handle broadcasting (e.g., batched matmul)

  • To use np.einsum or np.matmul for ND tensors

  • To include gradient clipping or more graph traversal safety

You said:
does this grad work like a linked list where the gradient what the previous one was an you can go back in time or is it just the gradient of the current tensor
ChatGPT said:

Great question this touches on the core of how automatic differentiation works.

Short answer:

No, the .grad on a tensor does not act like a "linked list" of past gradients. It represents the accumulated gradient of the current tensor with respect to the final output that is, its the gradient of the loss (or output) with respect to that tensor.

So:

  • It doesnt store intermediate steps

  • It doesnt let you go "back in time" unless you manually track those steps

  • But the computation graph (via _parents and _backward) does represent the full path backward

In more detail:

When you do:

python
C = A * B + D
C.backward()

  • The .grad values on A, B, and D become:

    • CA\frac{\partial C}{\partial A}AC

    • CB\frac{\partial C}{\partial B}BC

    • CD\frac{\partial C}{\partial D}DC

They are derivatives of the final output with respect to each tensor, not intermediate values from earlier steps.

So how do you go back in the graph?

Through the computation graph:

  • Each tensor stores references to its parents

  • Each tensor stores a custom backward function

  • When you call .backward(), it walks recursively from output input

This is how backpropagation works by chaining derivatives backward.

So in a sense, you do go back in time, but not through .grad through _parents and _backward().

If you wanted to store gradients over time (like during training steps):

You'd need to manually:

  • Copy tensor.grad into another variable (e.g., for momentum, Adam, etc.)

  • Or store gradients after each .backward() pass

Visual analogy:

  • .grad: Like a final scorecard whats the gradient of the loss w.r.t. this variable?

  • _backward + _parents: Like a map of all previous steps allows you to replay and propagate error backward

Would you like to see a visualization of the computation graph or how to track and store per-step gradients manually?

You said:
so do i need to store _parents or _nackard i thought was optional
ChatGPT said:

Excellent insight lets clarify:

You dont strictly need _parents or _backward if:

  • You're doing manual differentiation

  • You're building a static computation (like symbolic differentiation)

  • You're only doing forward computation, not autodiff

But if you want to support automatic differentiation (backpropagation), then:

You must store:

  1. _backward a custom function that defines how to compute the gradient for that operation

  2. _parents the input tensors to this operation, so you can recursively propagate gradients back

This is what allows the chain rule to work automatically.

Why _parents is important:

When you call .backward() on the final tensor:

  • It calls output._backward()

  • That function computes gradients w.r.t. its parents

  • Then it calls .backward() on each parent recursively

No _parents = no way to know where to send the gradients next.

Why _backward is important:

Every operation (like +, *, matmul, relu) needs to define how the output gradient maps to input gradients.

Without _backward, there's no way to define how to distribute the gradient backward.

So TL;DR:

ComponentRequired for Autodiff?Purpose
.grad YesStores the actual gradient value
_parents YesTo know where to propagate the gradient
_backward YesTo compute and apply the gradient rule for the operation

You can optimize or cache things later, but these are the core parts of an autodiff system (like PyTorchs dynamic computation graph).

Would you like an example showing what breaks if you leave out _parents or _backward?

You said:
so in c++ would this be a list of the previous states?
ChatGPT said:

In C++, yes if you're implementing autodiff, you'd typically represent the computation graph using something like a list (or vector) of pointers to parent tensors.

These arent really previous states in time theyre the input tensors to the current operation. Think of them as nodes in a computation graph, not a sequential history or list of snapshots.

In your C++ autodiff Tensor class

You might have:

cpp
std::vector<std::shared_ptr<Tensor<T>>> parents;
std::function<void()> backward_fn;

So what is this really?

  • parents: The inputs used to produce this tensor (like A and B in C = A * B)

  • backward_fn: A closure/function that tells you how to compute gradients for the parents based on this tensors gradient

Analogy to computation graph

Lets say you have:

cpp
auto A = Tensor<float>::create(2.0, true);
auto B = Tensor<float>::create(3.0, true);
auto C = A * B;    // stores A and B as parents
auto D = C + A;    // stores C and A as parents

Now when you call:

cpp
D->backward();

The traversal looks like:

mathematica
   A     B
    \   /
     C (= A * B)
      \
       D (= C + A)

So D needs to:

  1. Call its backward_fn to update C and A

  2. Then C calls its backward_fn, which updates A and B

Does this store the previous states?

  • No: You dont store values over time (like in an optimizer or RNN)

  • Yes: You do store the input tensors for gradient propagation

So its more accurate to think of it as a graph of inputs, not a temporal history.

In practice, in C++:

Youd have something like:

cpp
template<typename T>
class Tensor {
public:
    std::vector<std::shared_ptr<Tensor<T>>> parents;
    std::function<void()> backward_fn;

    void backward(T grad = 1.0) {
        if (!requires_grad) return;
        gradient += grad;
        if (backward_fn) {
            backward_fn();
            for (auto& p : parents) {
                p->backward();  // recursively propagate
            }
        }
    }
};

TL;DR:

  • Yes, in C++ this is usually a std::vector<std::shared_ptr<Tensor<T>>>

  • It tracks the computation graph, not the execution history

  • Needed for backpropagation, not for versioning or time travel

You said:

auto C = A \* B; // stores A and B as parents auto D = C + A; // stores C and A as parents

but woudnt C,A,B change over time so the information would not be accurate
ChatGPT said:

Thats a really sharp observation and it gets at a subtle but important point about how autodiff frameworks (like PyTorch, TensorFlow, etc.) manage computation graphs and tensor states.

You're right to ask:

Wouldn't A, B, and C change over time, and therefore the stored information (in parents) would be outdated?

Answer:
They could change over time, but they usually dont, because in autodiff systems:

  • Each operation creates a new tensor, rather than modifying the inputs in-place.

  • The computation graph is immutable once built like a snapshot of the math computation path.

  • parents points to the specific versions of A, B, C that were used during that operation.

Think of this like "persistent values"

When you do:

cpp
auto A = Tensor<float>::create(2.0f, true);
auto B = Tensor<float>::create(3.0f, true);
auto C = A * B;
auto D = C + A;

Each line creates a new Tensor instance. These are heap-allocated, and C stores a shared_ptr to the actual objects used in the operation.

So:

  • If later on you do A = some_new_tensor;, thats just reassigning the local variable A.

  • It does not affect the shared_ptr that was stored in C->parents.

In other words:

The computation graph points to the original objects not to the variable names or current state.

Quick analogy

cpp
auto A = Tensor<float>::create(2.0f, true);  // original A
auto B = Tensor<float>::create(3.0f, true);  // original B

auto C = A * B;  // C stores pointers to A and B
A = Tensor<float>::create(10.0f);  // A now points to a new tensor

// But C->parents[0] still points to the original A (value = 2.0)

So even though A the variable changed, C->parents[0] still points to the original object, and gradient propagation remains valid.

Conclusion

  • You're right that variable names can be reassigned, but:

  • The autodiff system stores actual object references (via shared_ptr, etc.)

  • As long as your design avoids in-place mutation of the tensor's .data, youre safe

  • This is one reason autodiff frameworks discourage raw in-place operations unless carefully tracked

You said:
so for tensor/matrix autodiff are we just doing the operations then applying the gradient to each individual element of the gradient beforehand whilst storing the original inputs so that on a backwards pass we can then proceed to undo the appilcation of the derivate and gain the derivative of wrt each of the two inputs
ChatGPT said:

Exactly! Youve nailed the core intuition behind autodiff for tensors and matrices. Let me break it down step-by-step and clarify a bit:

How tensor/matrix autodiff works in essence:

1. Forward pass:

  • You perform your tensor operations normally (e.g., add, multiply, matmul).

  • For each operation, you store the original input tensors used to compute the output.

  • You also store how to compute the gradient w.r.t. those inputs (the backward function).

Example:
For C = A.matmul(B) you save A, B, and a backward function that knows:

  • How to compute CA\frac{\partial C}{\partial A}AC

  • How to compute CB\frac{\partial C}{\partial B}BC

2. Backward pass:

  • Starting from the final output (usually a scalar loss), you set its gradient to 1 (because dlossdloss=1\frac{d \text{loss}}{d \text{loss}} = 1dlossdloss=1).

  • You call backward functions on each node in reverse order.

  • Each backward function:

    • Receives the gradient of the output w.r.t. itself (passed down from later nodes).

    • Computes gradients w.r.t. its inputs using the stored inputs and chain rule.

    • Accumulates those gradients in the .grad fields of the input tensors.

  • This repeats recursively until you get gradients w.r.t. all inputs you care about.

3. Gradient application:

During backward pass of each operation, the gradient is:

  • Element-wise multiplied or combined according to the derivative rule.

  • For example, for ReLU, the gradient is multiplied by an indicator function 1x>0\mathbf{1}_{x>0}1x>0.

  • For matmul, gradients come from matrix multiplication with transposes of the other input.

4. Why store original inputs?

Because to compute gradients for an operation, you often need:

  • The original input values e.g., in matmul backward, you use ATA^TAT and BTB^TBT.

  • The output gradient (passed down during backward pass).

  • With these, you compute partial derivatives w.r.t inputs.

Summary:

StepWhat happens?
Forward passCompute outputs; store inputs + backward func
Backward passUse stored info + output gradients to compute input gradients
Gradient stored.grad fields accumulate gradients element-wise

Visual Example for matmul:

Forward:

C=ABC = A \times BC=AB

Backward:

lossA=lossCBT\frac{\partial \text{loss}}{\partial A} = \frac{\partial \text{loss}}{\partial C} \times B^TAloss=ClossBT lossB=ATlossC\frac{\partial \text{loss}}{\partial B} = A^T \times \frac{\partial \text{loss}}{\partial C}Bloss=ATCloss

Here lossC\frac{\partial \text{loss}}{\partial C}Closs is the incoming gradient to the backward function (from later in the graph).

You said:
when storing the original input tensors do i need to copy the parents/backward functions of those tensors
ChatGPT said:

Great question! Here's how it works:

When you store the original input tensors inside a new tensor (the output of an operation):

  • You do NOT copy their parents or backward functions.

  • Instead, you store references (e.g., pointers or smart pointers) to those existing input tensors.

Why?

  • The inputs themselves already know their own computation graph (their own _parents and _backward).

  • By referencing the input tensors, you preserve the entire graph structure without duplicating it.

  • This allows you to traverse back recursively through the graph during .backward() calls.

So practically:

  • The output tensors parents just point to the input tensors.

  • Each input tensor already knows its own parents and backward logic.

  • During backward, you call the outputs backward function, which uses those inputs, then recursively call backward on the inputs, and so on.

To sum up:

Store in output tensorCopy?Reason
Input tensor objectsNo (store references)Keep graph structure intact, avoid duplication
Parents of inputsNoAlready stored inside each input tensor
Backward functions of inputsNoAlready stored inside each input tensor

If you copied parents/backward of inputs, you'd duplicate and bloat the graph, potentially causing inconsistencies and huge memory usage.

Let me know if you want an example showing how to do this safely with smart pointers in C++!

You said:
so to fully understand I have an input tensor and a NN. For each layer i will perform operations and (potentially a activation function) on those tensors which will then transform it to another tensor (potentially of a different shape) for each of these operations i store the inputs and a reference to the function i should call to undo/compute the gradient. This will hapen for all of the layers until i get to the output layer Here i calculate the loss and then use this loss to propgate backwards by calling the backwards function on by output tensor along witht the loss. Then it will go through and calcluate the gradients using the _gradientFuncsions as well as the _parent/input tensors
ChatGPT said:

Exactly thats a perfect summary! Heres a slightly expanded version to tie it all together cleanly:

Step-by-step walkthrough of what happens:

1. Forward pass:

  • Start with an input tensor.

  • Pass it through each layer of your neural network:

    • Each layer performs some tensor operations (like matrix multiply, add bias).

    • Each layer may apply an activation function (like ReLU).

  • Each operation creates a new tensor that:

    • Stores references to its input tensors (parents).

    • Stores a backward function that knows how to compute gradients w.r.t. those inputs.

This creates a computation graph representing all operations from input to output.

2. Loss computation:

  • Once you get the output tensor, you compute a loss scalar (e.g., MSE, cross-entropy).

  • This loss tensor becomes the starting point for backpropagation.

3. Backward pass (backpropagation):

  • Call .backward() on the loss tensor.

  • This:

    • Sets the loss gradient to 1 (since lossloss=1\frac{\partial loss}{\partial loss} = 1lossloss=1).

    • Calls the loss tensors backward function.

  • The backward function uses:

    • The stored input tensors (parents).

    • The stored gradient functions to compute gradients w.r.t. those inputs.

  • It then recursively calls .backward() on the parents, propagating gradients backward through the whole graph.

  • At each tensor, .grad fields accumulate gradients of the loss w.r.t. those tensors.

4. Result:

  • After backward finishes, every tensor that requires_grad has its .grad field set.

  • These gradients are what optimizers use to update the model parameters.

Visual summary:

text
Input tensor
     
Layer 1 (matmul, activation)
     
Layer 2 (matmul, activation)
     
...
     
Output tensor  Loss scalar

Backward starts here:
Loss.backward()   propagate gradients through all layers  gradients on all inputs

So yes, exactly:

  • Store inputs and backward function for each tensor.

  • Call .backward() on output tensor with loss.

  • Use stored info to compute gradients for each layer/input recursively.

You said:
and where does the weight updating take place
ChatGPT said:

Great question! The weight updating happens after the backward pass has computed all the gradients. Heres how it fits into the workflow:

Where does weight updating happen?

1. During forward and backward:

  • You do not update weights while computing forward or backward passes.

  • Forward pass: compute outputs.

  • Backward pass: compute gradients for all tensors that require gradients (like weights).

2. After backward finishes:

  • Now, each parameter tensor (e.g., weights and biases) has its .grad field filled with the gradient of the loss w.r.t. that parameter.

  • This is when optimizers come into play.

3. Optimizer step (weight update):

  • An optimizer (like SGD, Adam) uses the stored gradients to update the weights.

  • Example (SGD):

    cpp
    weight.data = weight.data - learning_rate * weight.grad;

  • This step modifies the weights data in-place.

  • After updating, the gradients are usually reset to zero for the next training iteration.

4. Training loop:

pseudo
for each batch:
    output = model.forward(input)
    loss = compute_loss(output, target)
    loss.backward()                # compute gradients
    optimizer.step()               # update weights using gradients
    optimizer.zero_grad()          # clear gradients for next iteration

Summary

PhaseWhat happens
Forward passCompute outputs
Backward passCompute gradients and store in .grad
Weight updateUse .grad to adjust weight.data

You said:
so the optimiser holds a reference to each layer which then can zero out each tensor? So is each layer represented by a tensor and that is the tensor which needs to calculate the gradient for I am trying to think about this visually as a tensor/block moving through a NN/graph
ChatGPT said:

You're on the right track visualizing this! Let me help clarify and connect the dots a bit:

1. Is each layer represented by a tensor?

  • No, not exactly.

  • A layer is usually a collection of parameters and operations for example:

    • A linear layer has weight tensors and bias tensors (parameters).

    • It also has the logic of how to apply those weights (matrix multiply + add).

  • So a layer holds one or more parameter tensors (like weights and biases).

2. Which tensors need gradients?

  • The parameter tensors inside each layer (weights, biases) need .grad computed.

  • Input and intermediate tensors produced during forward pass also track gradients if needed (e.g., activations), but parameters are the ones the optimizer updates.

3. How does the optimizer hold references?

  • The optimizer typically holds references/pointers to the parameter tensors (weights, biases).

  • It does not hold the whole layer, just the tensors it needs to update.

  • Example:

    cpp
    class Optimizer {
    std::vector<std::shared_ptr<Tensor<float>>> params;
public:
    void step() {
        for (auto& p : params) {
            // update p->data using p->grad
        }
    }
    void zero_grad() {
        for (auto& p : params) {
            p->grad.zero();
        }
    }
};

4. Visualizing the tensor flow through the network

Imagine the computation graph like a pipeline:

scss
Input Tensor
     (matmul + add bias)
Hidden Layer Output Tensor
     (activation function)
Next Layer Input Tensor
     ...
Output Tensor

  • Each tensor is a block with data and gradient info.

  • Layers are collections of parameter tensors plus code to produce new tensors from inputs.

  • The graph connects these tensors via operations.

  • During backpropagation, gradients flow backward along these connections.

Summary:

ConceptDescription
LayerCollection of parameters (tensors) + operations
Parameter TensorWeights/bias tensors inside layers
OptimizerHolds references to parameter tensors; updates them
Forward passData flows through tensors and operations
Backward passGradients flow backward through tensors

Absolutely! Heres a simple visualization of a neural networks computation graph using Mermaid syntax, which nicely illustrates tensors flowing through layers, their connections, and where gradients flow back during backpropagation.

Mermaid Diagram of a Simple 2-Layer Neural Network Computation Graph

mermaid
graph TD
    Input["Input Tensor (X)"]
    W1["Weight Tensor W1"]
    B1["Bias Tensor B1"]
    L1_Out["Layer 1 Output Tensor (Z1)"]
    Act1["Activation (ReLU)"]
    W2["Weight Tensor W2"]
    B2["Bias Tensor B2"]
    L2_Out["Layer 2 Output Tensor (Z2)"]
    Loss["Loss Scalar"]

    %% Forward pass connections
    Input -->|matmul| L1_Out
    W1 -->|matmul| L1_Out
    B1 -->|add| L1_Out
    L1_Out --> Act1
    Act1 -->|input| L2_Out
    W2 -->|matmul| L2_Out
    B2 -->|add| L2_Out
    L2_Out --> Loss

    %% Backward pass (gradients) - dashed arrows
    Loss -.-> L2_Out
    L2_Out -.-> W2
    L2_Out -.-> B2
    L2_Out -.-> Act1
    Act1 -.-> L1_Out
    L1_Out -.-> W1
    L1_Out -.-> B1
    L1_Out -.-> Input

Explanation:

  • Forward pass (solid arrows):

    • Input tensor and weight tensors combine (matmul), biases add, producing Layer 1 output.

    • Layer 1 output passes through activation (ReLU).

    • Activated output is input for Layer 2, again multiplied by weights, bias added.

    • Final output goes to the loss function.

  • Backward pass (dashed arrows):

    • Gradients flow backward from loss to all tensors involved.

    • Each tensors backward function uses stored inputs to compute gradients for parameters and previous tensors.

How to read this:

  • Boxes represent tensors.

  • Solid arrows show data flow forward.

  • Dashed arrows show gradients flowing backward.

  • Parameters (weights, biases) are leaf tensors updated by the optimizer.

  • Intermediate tensors are computed during forward pass and have gradients computed during backward pass.

  • Layer 1 neurons: n1_1, n1_2.

  • Layer 2 neuron (output): n2_1.

  • Each weight connects a neuron from the previous layer to the next.

  • Biases added per neuron.

  • Forward pass flows from inputs hidden layer output.

  • Backward pass gradients flow back from output neuron to hidden neurons, then to inputs.

You said:
and ho do special layer such as flattening or CNN work?
ChatGPT said:

Great question! Special layers like Flatten and Convolutional (CNN) layers work a bit differently but still fit into the same computation graph and autodiff framework. Heres how:

1. Flatten layer

  • Purpose: Convert a multi-dimensional tensor (e.g., 3D image: channels height width) into a 1D tensor (vector) so it can be fed into fully connected layers.

  • Forward pass:

    • Reshape the tensor without changing data.

    • Example: from shape [batch, channels, height, width] [batch, channels height width].

  • Backward pass:

    • Gradients arriving at the flattened output tensor are reshaped back to the original multi-dimensional shape.

    • So flattens backward just reshapes the gradient tensor.

2. Convolutional layer (CNN)

  • Purpose: Apply convolution filters to extract spatial features from input data (e.g., images).

  • Forward pass:

    • Slide filters (kernels) over input tensor spatial dimensions.

    • Perform element-wise multiplications and sum to get output feature maps.

    • Resulting tensor usually has shape [batch, out_channels, out_height, out_width].

  • Backward pass:

    • Compute gradients w.r.t:

      • Input tensor (for backprop to previous layers).

      • Filter weights (to update kernels).

      • Biases (if used).

    • Uses convolution operations in reverse (called transposed convolution or gradient convolution).

3. How do these fit in the computation graph?

  • Flatten:

    • Treated as a node with a reshape operation.

    • Stores the input tensor shape during forward to reshape gradients properly during backward.

  • Convolution:

    • Treated as a tensor operation node.

    • Stores inputs and filter tensors.

    • Backward function performs convolutions to compute gradients of inputs and filters.

4. Summary

Layer TypeForward PassBackward Pass
FlattenReshape tensor (no data change)Reshape gradient to input shape
ConvolutionConvolve input with filtersCompute gradients for input and filters

5. Visual analogy

Think of these layers as special blocks in your graph:

  • Flatten block: reshapes data flow without changing values.

  • Convolution block: slides a small window (kernel) over inputs and applies math, then in backward slides filters back to distribute gradients.

ChatGPT said:

Absolutely! Heres a clear and accurate summary of our entire chat so far:

Summary: Understanding Tensors, Computation Graphs, Autodiff, and Neural Networks

1. Computation Graph & Tensors

  • A computation graph is a way to represent a function as a graph where each node is a tensor operation.

  • In machine learning, neural networks and their computations are represented as computation graphs.

  • Each tensor operation (like add, multiply, matmul) creates nodes that hold references to input tensors and the operation used.

  • Forward pass computes the values; backward pass computes gradients by traversing the graph in reverse.

2. Tensors in Machine Learning vs. Math/Physics

  • In math and physics, tensors are multi-dimensional arrays with specific transformation properties.

  • In ML, tensors are primarily multi-dimensional arrays (n-dimensional arrays) for holding data and parameters.

  • The core mathematical understanding required includes linear algebra (vectors, matrices), calculus (derivatives), and some tensor algebra.

3. Autodiff & Gradients

  • Autodiff automatically computes gradients by chaining local derivatives through the computation graph.

  • Each tensor stores:

    • Its data.

    • Whether it requires gradient (requires_grad).

    • A pointer to its gradient tensor.

    • References to its parent tensors and the backward function to compute gradients.

  • During backpropagation:

    • The loss tensors .backward() is called.

    • Gradients propagate backward through the graph using stored backward functions.

  • This setup allows efficient calculation of gradients without symbolic math or numerical approximation.

4. Tensor Class Design Considerations

  • Use std::vector<T> internally for safe, dynamic storage of data.

  • The tensor class should be a template to support float, double, or custom numeric types.

  • Store shape, data, gradient, requires_grad flag, and backward function pointers.

  • Implement operations like add, multiply, matmul, divide, subtract, and overload operators for syntactic convenience.

  • Backward functions and parents are stored to support gradient computation.

  • Returning new tensor objects after operations supports immutability and safer memory management.

5. Memory Management and References

  • Use smart pointers (std::shared_ptr or std::unique_ptr) to manage tensor lifetimes.

  • Returning references to internal smart pointers needs care to avoid dangling references.

  • Immutable design pattern (returning new tensors) is safer and clearer.

  • Optimizer holds references only to parameter tensors (weights/biases), not the entire layers.

  • Optimizer steps update weights after gradients are computed, then zero out gradients for the next iteration.

6. Neural Network Flow (Visualized)

  • Forward pass: Input layers output loss

  • Backward pass: Loss output layers input, computing gradients along the way

  • Each layer:

    • Has parameters (tensors).

    • Applies operations producing output tensors.

    • Stores computation graph connections for backpropagation.

7. Activation Layers & Gradients

  • Activation functions (like ReLU) are separate operations.

  • Gradients for activations are computed by chaining backward functions.

  • Gradient flow resembles a linked graph, not a simple list.

  • Storing parents and backward functions is necessary to trace gradient flow properly.

8. Special Layers: Flatten and CNN

  • Flatten: Reshapes tensors without changing data; backward reshapes gradients back.

  • CNN layers: Perform convolutions in forward pass; backward pass computes gradients w.r.t inputs and filters using convolution transpose operations.

  • These layers integrate into the computation graph like other tensor operations.

9. Saving the Chat

  • Without logging in, your chat wont be saved automatically.

  • You can manually copy-paste, screenshot, or save the page.

  • If logged in, chats are saved automatically and can be accessed anytime.

You said:
for the implementation of the backwards function would i create a general backwards function for each operation eg backwards_add, backwards_mult backwards_sub and then store a stack of function pointers Then for the backwards pass, destack the pointer and call the function until the stack is empty
ChatGPT said:

Exactly! Youve nailed the core idea of how autograd/backprop works under the hood.

Heres a bit more detail to clarify and expand your idea:

1. Backward Functions per Operation

  • For each tensor operation, you define a specific backward function, e.g.:

    • backward_add

    • backward_multiply

    • backward_subtract

    • backward_matmul

    • etc.

  • Each backward function knows how to compute gradients w.r.t its input tensors, using the chain rule.

2. Storing Backward Functions

  • When you do a forward operation, you:

    • Create a new output tensor.

    • Store references to the input tensors (parents).

    • Store a pointer to the corresponding backward function for this operation inside the output tensor.

3. Backward Pass (Gradient Propagation)

  • Start by calling .backward() on the final output tensor (usually the loss), initializing its gradient to 1.

  • Use a stack or queue (or any graph traversal structure) to keep track of tensors whose gradients need to be computed.

  • While the stack is not empty:

    • Pop a tensor.

    • Call its stored backward function.

    • This computes gradients for its parents and adds them to the parents .grad tensors.

    • Push parent tensors onto the stack if they require gradient and havent been processed yet.

4. Why a Stack/Queue?

  • The graph may be a DAG (directed acyclic graph), not a simple chain.

  • Using a stack or queue lets you do a topological traversal of the graph backward.

  • This ensures every tensors gradient is computed after its dependents.

5. Example Sketch

cpp
// Pseudocode for a Tensor class method

void Tensor::backward() {
    if (!this->requires_grad) return;

    if (this->grad.is_empty())
        this->grad = Tensor::ones_like(this->shape);  // Seed grad for loss tensor

    std::stack<Tensor*> stack;
    std::set<Tensor*> visited;

    stack.push(this);

    while (!stack.empty()) {
        Tensor* current = stack.top();
        stack.pop();

        if (current->backward_fn) {
            current->backward_fn(current);  // Computes grads for parents
        }

        for (auto* parent : current->parents) {
            if (parent->requires_grad && visited.find(parent) == visited.end()) {
                stack.push(parent);
                visited.insert(parent);
            }
        }
    }
}

Summary

  • Backward functions per op handle gradient math for that op.

  • Store these functions linked to each tensor during forward pass.

  • Use a stack or queue to traverse backward in graph order.

  • Compute and accumulate gradients at each step.

You said:
and the output of the backwards function would be what? all of the gradient tensors or would each tensor in the NN have a gradient and we create a pointer to the weights/bias tensors and calculate with them on a backwards pass If so does this means that we recurse through tensors jumping from the output down or do we stay in the output and perform the operations in the output
ChatGPT said:

Great questions! Let me clarify how the backward function's outputs and the flow work in autodiff for neural networks:

1. What does the backward function output?

  • The backward function does not return gradient tensors explicitly.

  • Instead, it computes gradients with respect to each input tensor and accumulates them inside those input tensors .grad fields.

So for example, if you have:

cpp
Tensor C = A + B;

  • C stores a backward function like backward_add.

  • When you call C.backward(), it triggers backward_add, which:

    • Calculates C/A and C/B multiplied by upstream gradients.

    • Adds these gradients directly to A.grad and B.grad.

2. Does each tensor have its own .grad?

  • Yes! Each tensor with requires_grad=true has a .grad tensor.

  • This .grad tensor accumulates the gradients flowing back through all paths in the graph.

3. How do you traverse the graph?

  • You start from the output tensor (e.g., loss) and call .backward() on it.

  • The .backward() function traverses the computation graph backward by:

    • Calling each tensors stored backward function.

    • These backward functions compute gradients and update the .grad of input tensors.

  • This traversal can be recursive or use an explicit stack/queue for iterative topological order.

4. Do you stay in the output tensor or jump around?

  • Conceptually, you jump around the graph:

    • You call backward on the output tensor.

    • Its backward function updates parents gradients.

    • Then you call backward on those parents.

    • And so on, until you reach tensors with no parents (usually inputs or parameters).

  • This process is like walking backward through the graph nodes.

5. Where do weights and biases fit?

  • Weights and biases are tensors themselves with requires_grad=true.

  • During backprop:

    • Their .grad fields get populated.

    • Later, the optimizer uses those .grad tensors to update the weights/biases.

Summary of the flow:

  1. Start at output tensor (loss), set .grad to 1 (seed gradient).

  2. Call its backward function.

  3. Backward function computes and accumulates gradients into parents .grad fields.

  4. Recursively or iteratively call backward on parents.

  5. Continue until all needed tensors have their .grad.

  6. Optimizer updates weights using .grad fields.

If you'd like, I can show you a simplified C++ pseudocode example illustrating this backward propagation and gradient accumulation!

You said:
sure
ChatGPT said:

Heres a simplified C++-style pseudocode example illustrating the backward propagation flow with gradient accumulation for a toy Tensor class:

cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <memory>
#include <functional>
#include <stack>
#include <unordered_set>

template<typename T>
class Tensor {
public:
    std::vector<T> data;
    std::vector<int> shape;
    bool requires_grad = false;
    std::vector<T> grad;

    // Parents in the computation graph
    std::vector<std::shared_ptr<Tensor<T>>> parents;

    // Backward function to compute gradients for parents
    std::function<void(Tensor<T>*)> backward_fn;

    Tensor(std::vector<int> shape, bool requires_grad = false)
        : shape(shape), requires_grad(requires_grad)
    {
        int size = 1;
        for (auto s : shape) size *= s;
        data.resize(size, 0);
        if (requires_grad) {
            grad.resize(size, 0);
        }
    }

    // Example: Add operation producing a new tensor
    static std::shared_ptr<Tensor<T>> add(const std::shared_ptr<Tensor<T>>& a,
                                          const std::shared_ptr<Tensor<T>>& b) {
        auto out = std::make_shared<Tensor<T>>(a->shape, a->requires_grad || b->requires_grad);

        // Forward computation (element-wise add)
        for (size_t i = 0; i < out->data.size(); ++i)
            out->data[i] = a->data[i] + b->data[i];

        if (out->requires_grad) {
            out->parents = { a, b };

            // Define backward function for addition
            out->backward_fn = [a, b](Tensor<T>* self) {
                // The upstream gradient is stored in self->grad
                for (size_t i = 0; i < self->grad.size(); ++i) {
                    if (a->requires_grad)
                        a->grad[i] += self->grad[i];  // dC/dA = upstream grad
                    if (b->requires_grad)
                        b->grad[i] += self->grad[i];  // dC/dB = upstream grad
                }
            };
        }
        return out;
    }

    void backward() {
        if (!requires_grad) return;

        // Seed gradient for output tensor (e.g., loss)
        if (grad.empty() || std::all_of(grad.begin(), grad.end(), [](T v) { return v == 0; })) {
            for (auto& g : grad) g = 1; // dLoss/dLoss = 1
        }

        std::stack<Tensor<T>*> stack;
        std::unordered_set<Tensor<T>*> visited;

        stack.push(this);
        visited.insert(this);

        while (!stack.empty()) {
            Tensor<T>* current = stack.top();
            stack.pop();

            if (current->backward_fn)
                current->backward_fn(current);

            for (auto& parent : current->parents) {
                if (parent->requires_grad && visited.find(parent.get()) == visited.end()) {
                    stack.push(parent.get());
                    visited.insert(parent.get());
                }
            }
        }
    }
};

int main() {
    auto A = std::make_shared<Tensor<float>>(std::vector<int>{2}, true);
    auto B = std::make_shared<Tensor<float>>(std::vector<int>{2}, true);

    A->data = {2.0f, 3.0f};
    B->data = {1.0f, 4.0f};

    auto C = Tensor<float>::add(A, B);

    // Suppose C is the loss tensor
    C->backward();

    std::cout << "Gradient of A: ";
    for (auto g : A->grad) std::cout << g << " ";  // Expect [1,1]
    std::cout << "\n";

    std::cout << "Gradient of B: ";
    for (auto g : B->grad) std::cout << g << " ";  // Expect [1,1]
    std::cout << "\n";

    return 0;
}

Explanation:

  • add creates a new tensor with a backward function capturing inputs.

  • Calling C->backward() seeds gradient at output and traverses the graph backward.

  • The backward function adds the upstream gradient to each parents .grad.

  • Gradients accumulate in the parent tensors.

  • You can extend this pattern for other ops (multiply, matmul, etc.).

If you want, I can help you expand this for more complex operations or the full neural network layers!

so in pseudo code: C = A+B say this goes to A.add(B) In A: new Tensor C = A.data + B.data (for each element) C.addParent(this, B) C.addBackwardsFunction(backwardsAdd) return C
ChatGPT said:

Exactly, thats a great high-level pseudocode description! Heres a slightly more detailed version of what happens in your example:

pseudo
function Tensor.add(other):
    // 1. Create new tensor C with element-wise addition of A and B
    Tensor C = new Tensor(shape = broadcast_shape(this.shape, other.shape))
    for each index i in C:
        C.data[i] = this.data[i] + other.data[i]

    // 2. Set parents for backpropagation
    C.parents = [this, other]

    // 3. Assign backward function specific for addition
    C.backward_fn = function(self):
        // self.grad is the upstream gradient flowing into C
        for each index i in self.grad:
            if this.requires_grad:
                this.grad[i] += self.grad[i]
            if other.requires_grad:
                other.grad[i] += self.grad[i]

    // 4. Return the new tensor C
    return C

What happens next:

  • When C.backward() is called, it will call C.backward_fn(C), which distributes gradients back to A and B.

  • This chain continues back through the graph.

You said:
so will C only have one backwards function and not many
ChatGPT said:

Yes, exactly each tensor (like C) has only one backward function associated with how it was created.

Heres why:

  • A tensor in your computation graph is typically created by a single operation (e.g., addition, multiplication).

  • That operation defines one specific backward function for that tensor.

  • The backward function knows how to compute gradients with respect to its parent tensors (the inputs to that operation).

What about tensors used in multiple operations?

  • If a tensor is used in multiple downstream operations, each downstream tensor will have its own backward function.

  • But each tensor node stores only the backward function corresponding to the operation that produced it.

  • During the backward pass, gradients accumulate through all paths via the .grad fields of tensors, but each tensors backward function is singular.

Summary:

  • One tensor = one backward function (the op that created it).

  • Gradients flow backward through these functions.

  • Multiple paths accumulate gradients in the .grad field of parent tensors.

If you imagine the graph like a chain of operations, each tensor is a node created by exactly one op so it only needs one backward function. The full graph structure and multiple gradient flows happen because of the network of nodes and edges, not multiple backward functions per node.

You said:
and what about intermediate tensors such as in D = I*W +B Here an intermediate C might be created by I*W Then D would be created by C+B wouldnt C be a waste of memory since it is only an intermediate step and not an actual part of the NN
ChatGPT said:

Great observation! Intermediate tensors like C = I * W in D = C + B are indeed temporary, but they play a crucial role in the computation graph for forward and backward passes.

Why intermediate tensors (like C) are needed and not wasted memory:

  1. They represent computation steps:

    • Each intermediate tensor holds the result of an operation.

    • They store data needed for both:

      • The forward pass output

      • The backward pass (to compute gradients)

  2. They are nodes in the computation graph:

    • Backpropagation requires access to intermediate outputs and their parents.

    • The intermediate tensor C stores:

      • Its data (output of I*W)

      • Its parents (I and W)

      • Its backward function (for matrix multiplication)

    • Without C, you cant compute gradients correctly.

  3. Memory can be optimized but not eliminated trivially:

    • Some frameworks use memory optimization techniques:

      • In-place operations

      • Gradient checkpointing (recomputing intermediates instead of storing)

      • Deleting intermediates after backward pass

    • But conceptually, you need these intermediates to track gradient flow.

  4. In a neural network:

    • W and B are parameters (weights, biases), which you want to keep.

    • I, the input, is fixed.

    • Intermediate tensors like C are temporary results but necessary for autodiff.

Visual analogy:

sql
I ------\
         * (matmul) --> C ------\
                                + (add) --> D
B -----------------------------/

  • C stores the result and backward info for I * W.

  • D stores the result and backward info for C + B.

Summary:

  • Intermediate tensors are necessary to build the computation graph.

  • They hold outputs and backward info needed to calculate gradients.

  • Theyre temporary in the logical sense, but crucial for autodiff.

  • Optimizations can reduce their memory footprint, but the concept remains.

You said:
so just theoretically how much storage would a small NN need for this since we are creating a lot of references and tempory variables
ChatGPT said:

Great question estimating the memory footprint of a small neural network with autodiff can help understand practical constraints.

Memory components in a small NN with autodiff:

  1. Model parameters (weights & biases)
    Stored tensors with fixed shapes (usually the largest persistent memory cost).
    E.g., for a fully connected layer:

    • Weight matrix: size = input_dim output_dim

    • Bias vector: size = output_dim

  2. Intermediate tensors (activations)
    Every forward operation produces intermediate outputs (activations) stored as tensors. These are required for backprop.

    • For each layer, you store the output tensor

    • Also, you keep parents and backward function references (small overhead)

  3. Gradients
    Each tensor with requires_grad has an associated gradient tensor of the same size as its data.

    • So gradients roughly double the memory cost of parameters.

  4. Computation graph metadata
    For each tensor, you store:

    • References/pointers to parents (usually a few pointers per tensor)

    • A function pointer or lambda for the backward operation

    • Some bookkeeping (flags, shapes, etc.)

Rough memory estimate example for a small NN

Assume a small 3-layer fully connected network:

  • Input layer: 100 units

  • Hidden layer: 50 units

  • Output layer: 10 units

Parameters:

  • W1: 100 50 = 5,000 floats (~20 KB)

  • b1: 50 floats (~0.2 KB)

  • W2: 50 10 = 500 floats (~2 KB)

  • b2: 10 floats (~0.04 KB)

Total params ~22.2 KB

Activations (forward pass):

  • Layer1 output: 50 floats (~0.2 KB)

  • Layer2 output (final output): 10 floats (~0.04 KB)

Gradients:

  • Same size as params (22.2 KB)

  • Same size as activations if you need to backprop through inputs

Overhead (parents/backward functions):

  • A few pointers (~8 bytes each) per tensor, negligible compared to data

Total memory roughly:

  • Parameters + gradients: ~44.4 KB

  • Activations: ~0.3 KB

  • Metadata: a few KB max

What if you have batch inputs?

  • If batch size = 32, activations scale by 32 (activations per example batch size)

  • So activations can dominate memory usage in training

Key points:

  • Intermediate tensors add memory overhead but usually much smaller than parameters + gradients combined.

  • Batch size strongly affects total memory (activations scale with batch size).

  • References and backward functions add only small fixed overhead per tensor.

Summary:

Memory componentScaleNotes
ParametersNumber of weightsPersistent
GradientsSame size as parametersPersistent
ActivationsBatch size layer outputsGrows with batch size
MetadataNumber of tensorsSmall overhead

data\[i\] + other.data\[i\] // 2. Set parents for backpropagation C.parents = \[this, other\] // 3. Assign backward function specific for addition C.backward\_fn = function(self): // self.grad is the upstream gradient flowing into C for each index i in self.grad: if this.requires\_grad: this.grad\[i\] += self.grad\[i\] if other.requires\_grad: other.grad\[i\] += self.grad\[i\] // 4. shouldnt the backwards function also call the backwards functions for A and B so it can recurse
ChatGPT said:

Great question!

No, the backward function of a tensor typically does not directly call the backward functions of its parents. Instead, the backward pass is managed externally by a traversal of the computation graph.

Why?

  • Each tensors backward_fn computes local gradients with respect to its inputs (parents) and accumulates those gradients into the parents .grad.

  • The actual recursion or traversal through the graph is done by the backward engine (or your manual backward loop), which:

    • Calls the backward function of the output tensor first,

    • Then moves to its parents,

    • Calls their backward functions, and so on.

In other words:

  • C.backward_fn() only calculates gradients for A and B based on C.grad.

  • The framework or your backward loop is responsible for calling A.backward() and B.backward() later.

  • This separation avoids tangled recursive calls and allows the backward pass to be implemented as a graph traversal (often a topological order or using a stack).

To visualize:

pseudo
C.backward():
    C.backward_fn()  // computes gradients for A and B
    call A.backward()  // separately called by the backward traversal
    call B.backward()  // separately called by the backward traversal

Summary:

  • Backward function = local gradient computation only (updates parents .grad)

  • Backward traversal (outside the backward function) = responsible for recursively calling backward on parents

This design cleanly separates gradient calculation from graph traversal, making autodiff easier to manage and debug.

If you want, I can help you write the pseudocode for the backward traversal loop!

You said:
so if this is backwards propagation then where does gradient decent come in is this more maths?
ChatGPT said:

Exactly! Backward propagation (backprop) and gradient descent are two related but distinct steps in training a neural network.

What backward propagation (backprop) does:

  • It computes the gradients of the loss with respect to each parameter (weights, biases, etc.) in the network.

  • In other words, it answers:
    How does changing this parameter change the loss?

  • The output of backprop is all those gradient values stored in each parameters .grad.

What gradient descent does:

  • It uses those gradients to update the parameters in order to minimize the loss.

  • This is where the math of optimization comes in.

  • The simplest form:

    L\theta \leftarrow \theta - \eta \cdot \nabla_\theta LL

    where:

    • \theta = parameter

    • \eta = learning rate (step size)

    • L\nabla_\theta LL = gradient of loss w.r.t. parameter \theta

So the workflow is:

  1. Forward pass: Compute output and loss from input and parameters.

  2. Backward pass: Use backprop to compute gradients of loss w.r.t parameters.

  3. Parameter update: Use gradient descent (or an optimizer like Adam, RMSProp, etc.) to update parameters using those gradients.

  4. Repeat for many iterations/epochs.

Summary:

StepPurposeResult
Backward propagationCalculate gradients of loss.grad fields of parameters filled
Gradient descentUse gradients to update parametersParameters move towards minimum loss

If you want, I can show you how to implement a simple gradient descent optimizer that updates your tensors after backprop!

You said:
so gradient decent is in the optimisers
ChatGPT said:

Exactly! Gradient descent and its more advanced variants are implemented inside optimizers.

What optimizers do:

  • Take the current parameters (weights, biases, etc.)

  • Access their stored gradients (computed by backprop)

  • Update the parameters according to some rule, e.g.:

    • Vanilla Gradient Descent:

      L\theta \leftarrow \theta - \eta \cdot \nabla_\theta LL

    • Momentum: Adds a velocity term to smooth updates

    • Adam: Uses adaptive learning rates and momentum

So the typical training loop looks like:

pseudo
for each training batch:
    output = model.forward(input)
    loss = compute_loss(output, target)
    
    loss.backward()  // compute gradients via backprop
    
    optimizer.step()  // update parameters using gradients
    
    optimizer.zero_grad()  // clear gradients before next iteration

  • optimizer.step() is where gradient descent or more complex update logic happens.

  • zero_grad() resets gradients to zero so they dont accumulate across batches unless desired.

Summary:

  • Backpropagation = compute gradients

  • Optimizer = update parameters using gradients

They work hand-in-hand but are conceptually separate.

You said:
so most of the pseudo code reguarding the anonamous backwards function assumes that the parents gradients are public. This is not the case for c++ when trying to encapsulate them
ChatGPT said:

Exactly in C++, encapsulation means you typically dont want to make the .grad member public, but your autodiff backward functions need to access and modify the gradients of parent tensors.

This creates a bit of a design challenge.

How to handle gradient access in C++ while maintaining encapsulation?

Here are some common strategies:

1. Use friend classes/functions

  • Make your backward function (or the whole autodiff engine) a friend of the Tensor class.

  • This way, the backward functions can access private members like .grad directly.

cpp
class Tensor {
    template<typename T>
    friend class AutodiffEngine;  // or specific friend backward function

private:
    std::vector<T> grad;
    // ...
};

2. Provide controlled getters and setters

  • Provide member functions like:

cpp
class Tensor {
public:
    void addToGrad(const std::vector<T>& grad_to_add);
    const std::vector<T>& getGrad() const;

private:
    std::vector<T> grad;
};

  • Backward functions call addToGrad() to accumulate gradients without direct access.

3. Encapsulate backward logic inside the Tensor class or a trusted helper

  • Make backward functions methods of Tensor or a close helper class that can access private members.

  • This keeps gradient manipulation inside trusted code.

4. Use smart pointers or handles with restricted access

  • Your backward function could hold a pointer or reference to the parent tensor and call its public methods to modify gradients.

Which approach is best?

  • Depends on your design goals:

    • Friend functions are straightforward but loosen encapsulation.

    • Getter/setter methods keep encapsulation but add some boilerplate.

    • Keeping backward logic inside the class (or trusted helpers) balances safety and functionality.

Summary

In practice, most autodiff libraries either:

  • Use friendship or

  • Design an internal API so that backward functions can safely and efficiently update gradients without exposing private data publicly.

You said:
hold on there i have my gradient as a Tensor object
ChatGPT said:

Ah, that adds an interesting twist!

If your gradient itself is a Tensor object (not just a vector of floats), then the backward functions need to access and update the .data inside the gradient tensor.

Implications:

  • Your Tensor class contains something like:

cpp
template<typename T>
class Tensor {
private:
    std::vector<T> data;
    Tensor<T> grad;  // gradient is itself a Tensor
    // ...
};

  • Backward functions must update grad.data (or use methods on grad) to accumulate gradients.

How to handle this cleanly in C++?

  1. Friendship or internal API access:

    • The backward function must have access to the grad tensor's internal data (private data vector).

    • Either make backward functions friends of Tensor, or provide controlled interfaces like:

cpp
void addToGrad(const Tensor<T>& grad_to_add);
Tensor<T>& getGrad();

  1. Avoid direct public data access:

    • Dont expose data publicly.

    • Provide methods for element-wise operations, e.g., addInPlace(const Tensor<T>& other), so backward functions can accumulate gradients safely.

  2. Backprop updates gradients by calling methods on grad:

    • Example:

cpp
void backwardAdd(const Tensor<T>& upstream_grad) {
    this->grad.addInPlace(upstream_grad);
}

Why use Tensor for gradient?

  • Supports gradients of arbitrary shape (e.g., higher dimensional derivatives).

  • Makes chaining of gradients consistent with tensor operations.

  • Enables storing gradients w.r.t. multi-dimensional parameters naturally.

Summary

  • Storing gradients as Tensor objects is flexible and common.

  • Just ensure backward functions can access/update the gradient tensor's data via controlled APIs or friendship.

  • Encapsulation can be preserved by exposing safe methods to modify .grad instead of making internal data public.

You said:
so going back to the C = A+B This would be something like C.backwardsAdd = { if A.requiresGrad A.addGrad(this.grad); if B.requiresGrad B.addGrad(this.grad) } Which a Tensor.addGrad(Tensor& t){ this.grad.add(t); }
ChatGPT said:

Exactly! Youve got the right idea.

Heres a clearer version of how it works conceptually in C++-style pseudocode:

cpp
// In the forward pass when creating C = A + B
C.setBackwardFunction([&]() {
    if (A.requiresGrad()) {
        A.addGrad(C.grad);  // add gradient flowing from C back to A
    }
    if (B.requiresGrad()) {
        B.addGrad(C.grad);  // add gradient flowing from C back to B
    }
});

And your addGrad method inside Tensor might look like:

cpp
void addGrad(const Tensor<T>& grad_to_add) {
    // element-wise add grad_to_add to this->grad tensor
    this->grad = this->grad + grad_to_add;  // assuming operator+ defined for Tensor
}

Key points:

  • C.grad holds the gradient flowing back from later computations (initially, for output tensor, its usually set to 1).

  • When C.backward() is called, it runs the stored backward function (backwardsAdd in this case).

  • That backward function pushes gradient contributions to parents A and B by adding C.grad to their .grad.

  • This chaining continues backward through the graph until all gradients are computed.

You said:
and if im using std::function for the backwards_function how does this look
ChatGPT said:

Great question! Using std::function for storing the backward function is a neat and flexible way to implement this in C++. Heres what it might look like conceptually.

Example sketch:

cpp
#include <functional>
#include <memory>

template<typename T>
class Tensor {
public:
    // Data for this tensor
    std::vector<T> data;

    // Gradient tensor
    Tensor<T> grad;

    // Flag for whether to compute gradient
    bool requires_grad = false;

    // Backward function stored as std::function<void()>
    std::function<void()> backward_function;

    // Method to run backward pass for this tensor
    void backward() {
        if (backward_function) {
            backward_function();
        }
    }

    // Add grad contribution
    void addGrad(const Tensor<T>& grad_to_add) {
        // Example: element-wise add grad_to_add.data to grad.data
        for (size_t i = 0; i < grad.data.size(); ++i) {
            grad.data[i] += grad_to_add.data[i];
        }
    }
};

// Function for forward addition of tensors A + B producing C
template<typename T>
Tensor<T> add(const Tensor<T>& A, const Tensor<T>& B) {
    Tensor<T> C;
    // Assume same shape for simplicity, element-wise addition
    C.data.resize(A.data.size());
    for (size_t i = 0; i < A.data.size(); ++i) {
        C.data[i] = A.data[i] + B.data[i];
    }

    C.requires_grad = A.requires_grad || B.requires_grad;

    if (C.requires_grad) {
        // Capture references to A, B, and C by reference for the backward function
        C.backward_function = [&]() {
            if (A.requires_grad) {
                // Add C.grad to A.grad
                const_cast<Tensor<T>&>(A).addGrad(C.grad);
            }
            if (B.requires_grad) {
                // Add C.grad to B.grad
                const_cast<Tensor<T>&>(B).addGrad(C.grad);
            }
        };
    }

    return C;
}

Notes:

  • std::function<void()> backward_function; holds the lambda that runs during backprop.

  • The lambda captures references to parents and C so it can access their gradients.

  • Since A and B are const& parameters, but gradients need to be updated, you may need to use const_cast or design your API differently (e.g., pass non-const refs or pointers).

  • Youll want to manage lifetime carefully to ensure the captured references are valid during backward calls.

  • This approach keeps the backward logic nicely encapsulated and flexible.

If you want, I can help you extend this with memory management or handle the full backward graph traversal!

You said:
std::vector<unique_ptr<Tensor<T>>> parents; And this is fine?
ChatGPT said:

Using std::vector<std::unique_ptr<Tensor<T>>> parents; is technically valid C++, but whether its the best choice depends on how you want to manage ownership and lifetime of your parent tensors in your computation graph.

What does std::unique_ptr<Tensor<T>> mean here?

  • You own the parent tensors exclusively your tensor is responsible for their lifetime.

  • When your tensor is destroyed, its parents are destroyed too.

  • But this is usually not what you want for parents in a computation graph, because:

    • Parent tensors (e.g., inputs to multiple operations) are typically shared among multiple children.

    • You dont want to delete parents when a single child is destroyed.

    • The parents usually outlive or at least have independent lifetimes from children.

Typical alternatives:

  1. Use raw pointers or references (non-owning):

    cpp
    std::vector<Tensor<T>*> parents;

    • This means your tensor points to parents but does not own them.

    • Someone else (e.g., the computational graph or the user code) manages the parents lifetime.

    • You must be careful to ensure parents stay alive while children use them.

  2. Use std::shared_ptr for shared ownership:

    cpp
    std::vector<std::shared_ptr<Tensor<T>>> parents;

    • Parents are shared between children.

    • Parents are destroyed when no tensor points to them anymore.

    • Adds some overhead of reference counting, but safer lifetime management.

So: is std::unique_ptr fine here?

  • Usually no, because parents are shared nodes.

  • Using unique_ptr means you want exclusive ownership, which breaks sharing and can cause dangling pointers or double deletions.

Summary recommendation:

  • Use non-owning raw pointers if you manage tensor lifetimes elsewhere and want minimal overhead.

  • Use std::shared_ptr if you want automatic shared lifetime management.

  • Avoid unique_ptr for parents in computation graphs, unless you specifically want exclusive ownership (rare in this context).

You said:
wouldnt the NN have ownership of the tensors
ChatGPT said:

Yes, exactly! Typically, the neural network (or the computation graph manager) owns the tensors, and individual tensors just hold non-owning references or pointers to their parents.

How it usually works:

  • The NN or graph manager creates and owns all tensors (inputs, weights, intermediate activations).

  • These are stored in containers (e.g., std::vector<std::unique_ptr<Tensor<T>>> or std::vector<std::shared_ptr<Tensor<T>>>).

  • Each tensors parents are non-owning raw pointers or weak pointers that refer back to the tensors owned by the NN.

  • This avoids multiple ownership and ensures:

    • Lifetime is centrally managed.

    • No accidental double deletes.

    • Parents stay alive while children use them.

Example:

cpp
class NeuralNetwork {
    std::vector<std::unique_ptr<Tensor<T>>> all_tensors;  // owns all tensors

    // Tensors inside the graph hold:
    // std::vector<Tensor<T>*> parents;  // non-owning pointers to parents
};

Why?

  • Ownership: Only one place manages lifetime (the NN).

  • Flexibility: Tensors can safely refer to parents without worrying about deleting them.

  • Efficiency: No overhead of reference counting unless you specifically want shared ownership.

Summary

  • Yes, the NN owns the tensors.

  • Tensors keep non-owning references to parents.

  • This design is common in C++ autodiff and NN libs.
